abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Fertilizer Industry
            Rehabilitation Project for Pakistan was successful. The
            project fully accomplished its objectives, its impact has
            been substantial, sustainability is likely, and both the
            Bank and Borrower performed satisfactorily. Several lessons
            can be learned from this project. First, a competent,
            adequately staffed project team must be established in the
            early stage of project execution. Second, use of capable and
            experienced engineering and construction contractors should
            be carefully planned and carried out. Third, bonus and
            penalty clauses in engineering and construction contracts
            should be carefully used to expedite project execution.
            Fourth, cumbersome government/company procedures need to be
            streamlined for early clearance of project design and
            procurement recommendations. Fifth, intensive technical
            supervision by the Bank is necessary at the stage of project
            design and bidding by engineering contractors. Sixth,
            participation of experienced expatriate consultants through
            technical assistance agreements helps coordination of the
            activities of various contractors and vendors in the course
            of project execution. Seventh, adequate training of
            personnel is necessary. Eighth, assignment of company
            personnel to the offices of engineering and construction
            contractors is essential. Lastly, recruitment of competent
            staff with competitive compensation scales is essential to
            ensure smooth project execution and operation.
